@jai1 Updated

@yush1ga @nkurihar Sorry for delay on this one. The only concern I have is that the "timeout" for the delete subscription is reset each time a broker is restarted. So if you have a 2 weeks auto-deletion, and restart brokers frequently that would not be applied, or much later that one wold expect.
And so the amount of storage would be higher (compared to the TTL approach).
@rdhabalia Change looks good, though how does the affinity works for global namespaces? v2 namespaces are basically always treated as "global" (with one or more clusters assigned)

> though how does the affinity works for global namespaces?

yes, I also realized it, with v2 it won't work as it is because failure-domain contains list of brokers and these failure-domain list is attached to a cluster. so, we need a place-holder to keep list of failure-domains. 
Should we create a failure-domain znode under `/admin` in local zk and use it if `/admin/clusters/MY_CLUSTER` not present?
retest this please
Rebased to master
My question was more of how does it work now with v1 global namespaces?

> My question was more of how does it work now with v1 global namespaces?

While assigning namespace bundle ownership, LoadManager considers two things: (1) get list of failure-domains (where each domain will have list of brokers) (2) for a requested bundle, get group of anti affinity namespaces (from namespace policies). Then load manager tries to select broker from failure domains so, this anti-affinity namespaces get distributed uniformly across these failure domains.

with V2, namespace policies will not be changed so, 2nd part will not be affected. however, we store failure domain in global zk under `/admin/clusters`. therefore, we can change this place-holder and store it in local zk so, each cluster will have its failure domain under `/admin/failure-domain` in local zk.

if this seems reasonable then I will create a PR with the change.
@merlimat Would you please help review this?
@merlimat Would you please help review this?
@merlimat Would you please help review this?

@rdhabalia Still few tests failing : 

```
org.apache.pulsar.broker.web.RestException: Cluster does not exist
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.admin.impl.ClustersBase.updateCluster(ClustersBase.java:156)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.admin.AdminTest.brokers(AdminTest.java:495)
```
I still don't see the difference, with respect to anti-affinity, between a v1 global namespace and v2 namespace. I think the same exact condition applies to both of them
Fix looks good, is it easy to reproduce this issue? Would it happen by having a thread acking messages and then other thread calling reset cursor?

> I still don't see the difference, with respect to anti-affinity, between a v1 global namespace and v2 namespace.

Yes, but with v2, I think the idea is to avoid using `clusters`. So, user don't have to create `/admin/clusters/<MY_CLUSTER>`. is that right? if yes, then `failure-domain` which is created under `/admin/clusters/<MY_CLUSTER>` can't be used if broker is not using clusters with v2. 
is that right?

> Yes, but with v2, I think the idea is to avoid using clusters

The idea is to treat all namespaces as "global". 

In v1 you have `tenant/global/namespace`, configured with `c1` and `c2`.
If v2, that would be `tenant/namespace` in the same way, configured with `c1` and `c2`.

`tenant/namespace` can either be non-replicated, (eg: if it only uses `c1` cluster) or replicated (if you later add a new cluster), without changing the namespace/topics names.
For the perspective of v1 logic, every v2 namespace is effectively "global"

> Would it happen by having a thread acking messages and then other thread calling reset cursor?

that's correct. [skipping entries](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/managed-ledger/src/main/java/org/apache/bookkeeper/mledger/impl/ManagedCursorImpl.java?utf8=%E2%9C%93#L1166) and acking happens in different thread.
It's little tricky to reproduce in unit-test, but I will try or will do it in separate PR.

> If v2, that would be tenant/namespace in the same way, configured with c1 and c2.

Hmm.. ok, then we still require cluster creation which will not be changed. so, we won't need change for failure-domain and it works as it is.
Correct, it's exactly the same as a v1 "global" topic

I hit the same issue and following steps have been helped.

As a **workaround** (for testing-purpose): 
Previous `/data` folder can be removed (will be created again automatically) and 
`bin/pulsar standalone` can be run again.

**Pulsar version:** 1.22.0
